The immediate post-war period continued to be difficult for the Liberal Party in terms of political positioning. National Joint Committee for Spanish Relief
response: The war in Spain broke out in July 1936. An appeal from Julio Álvarez del Vayo on behalf of the Spanish government led a group of six British Members of Parliament to visit Madrid in November 1936: they were F. Seymour Cocks, W. P. Crawford-Greene, D. R. Grenfell, Archibald James, John Macnamara and Wilfrid Roberts. Roberts, on the Parliamentary Group for Spain of 15 MPs, then proposed a National Joint Committee, announced at Friends House on 23 December 1936. It first met in January 1937, continuing in Parliament's committee rooms. The leaders that emerged were Roberts, the Duchess of Atholl, and Isobel Brown; the Duchess was Chairman, with Grenfell, Macnamara and Roberts as secretaries.
